# Grammars

## Adequacy

- **descriptively** adequate generates *all* grammatical s/phr, but *no*
  ungrammatical
- **explanatorily** adequate explains *why*

## Parts of Speech

N, V, Adj, Adv, Det, P, I, C

Not linear (tree-like)

### Some phrases

PP $\to$ P NP
NP $\to$ (Det) N'
N' $\to$ N (PP)

VP $\to$ (Adv) V'
VP $\to$ V IP
V' $\to$ V (NP)

IP $\to$ (NP) I'
I' $\to$ I VP (intuitively, an IP is a sentence)

CP $\to$ C IP

## Generative Grammer

Infinity from the finite
No upper limit to length of sentence
*Yet*, we master a finite vocabulary and finite grammer with finite capacities

**generative grammar** should generate an infinite set of phrases from a finite starting point (lexicon, rules)

Due to:

### Recursion

$\checkmark$

This infinity might still be not large enough to encompass *all* grammatical sentences
We need more.

### Long-Distance Dependencies

"Jane knows Mary will kiss John" is fine
\*"Jane knows Mary will kiss" fails because kiss requires a direct object...
But then... "Jane knows who Mary will kiss"

Movement phenomenon, tranformation, &c.
